publicationStmt.publisher: Digital Culture Lab, Department of Information and Library Science, Luddy School of Informatics, Computing, and Engineering, Indiana University

availability.p:
Creative Commons License
The Algernon Charles Swinburne Project, edited by John A. Walsh, is freely licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.

seriesStmt.title: The Algernon Charles Swinburne Project: A Digital Collection Devoted to the Life and Work of Victorian Poet Algernon Charles Swinburne.

bibl.ref: The Poems of Dante Gabriel Rossetti.
Morris’s Life and Death of Jason.
Notes on the Text of Shelley.
Notes on the Designs of the Old Masters at Florence.

note.p: A dramatic poem written in 1865 by Swinburne about the tragic mythological story of the queen of Calydon, Althaea, her son, Meleager, and his love for Atalanta.
A play written by Aristophanes about escaping wartime Athens to create a utopia.
A play written in 1874 by Swinburne about Mary Stuart's lover and eventual third husband, James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell. The second in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A dramatic poem written by William Mason in 1759 about the British chieftain, Caractacus, who led the British resistance against the Roman invasion in the middle of the 1st century.
A book of poetry by Catullus.
A play written in 1865 by Swinburne about a French poet and supposed lover of Mary Stuart, Chastelard. The first in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A second play in the series, Oresteia, written by Aeschylus. The play is about the reuniting of Orestes and his sister, Electra and their revenge against their mother, Clymnestra.
A painting by Sodoma displayed in the Sienese Academy in Siena, Italy.
An ode by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
Law issued by Constantine I that proclaimed religious tolerance across the Roman empire.
A dramatic poem written in 1876 by Swinburne about the ancient king of Athens often equated with Poseidon in Greek mythology.
An ode by Samuel Taylor Coleridge.
A book about the history of France up until the 15th century.
A drama written around 1599 by Shakespeare about the English King, Henry V, before and after the Battle of Agincourt in The Hundred Years' War against the French.

bibl.title: Henry VI, parts one, two, and three

note.p: A three-part play written by William Shakespeare, loosely based on the 15th century English politics and the rise of Henry VI to the English throne.
An epic poem attributed to Homer about the last years of the Trojan War.
A drama written around 1606 by Shakespeare about the pre-Roman king, Leir of Britain.
A Elizabethan drama of unknown authorship about King Leir and his three daughters. Written before Shakespeare's King Henry V around 1605.
A book of poems written by Callimachus.
A poem by Victor Hugo.
An Elizabethan play of unknown authorship about the founding of England.
A drama written in 1820 by Lord Byron about Faliero, the Doge of Venice, and his attempted coup d'etat in 1355.
A play written in 1881 by Swinburne. The second in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A dramatic poem written by Matthew Arnold in 1858 about the queen of the Messiana, a city in the Peloponnese region of Greece, whose husband is murdered by their son.
A novel written in 1862 by the French author, Victor Hugo, about the stuggles of the French after Napoleon's reign.
A tragic drama written around 1603 by Shakespeare about a Moorish General in the Venetian army.
A drama written in 1820 by Percey Bysshe Shelley about Zeus' torment of Prometheus for giving man fire.
A tragic, free verse drama written in 1899 by Swinburne.
A two-part play written by Christopher Marlowe, loosely based on the 14th century central Asia emperor, Timbur.

bibl.title: The Famous History of Sir Thomas Wyatt

note.p: A play written in 1607 by John Webster and Thomas Dekkar, based on the Elizabethan English poet, Sir Thomas Wyatt.

bibl.title: The Famous Victories of King Henry the Fifth

note.p: A Elizabethan drama of unknown authorship about the life of King Henry V. Written before Shakespeare's King Henry V.
A Roman copy of a Greek sculpture of the mythological Graces that was displayed in the main hall of the Sienese Academy in Siena, Italy in the mid 19th century.
Daughter of King Oedipus of Thebes and his mother, Jocasta. In Sophocles's Antigone, she fights for a proper burial for her brother, Polyneices, who was thought to be a traitor to Thebes.
English Elizabethan poet and soldier. Wrote Astrophel and Stella.
Older brother of Moses and a prophet.
Greek god of rebirth and vegetation.
Athenian Tragic Dramatist.
Ancient Greek Sophist and epistlographer.
A Greek demi-goddess, the daughter of Aeolus and wife of Ceyx, son of Eosphorus and the king of Thessaly.
Italian dramatist.
The great god of Egyptian Thebes, sometimes identified with Zeus. And name given to the oracle of the Temple of Ammon in Siwa. The oracle was thought to be the son of Zeus.
Lover of the Greek poet Sappho.
Character appearing in the sixth tale of the forth day in Boccaccio's Decameron. She is forced to proclaim her innocence after her lover, Gabriotto, dies when she recounts to him a recent dream.
Fictional author of the fictional epigraph to Swinburne's Laus Veneris.
Goddess of love and beauty, who rose from the sea born from the severed genitals of Uranus.
Greek god of music and poetry, son of Zeus and Leto.

A character in Shakespeare's and John Fletcher's play, The Two Noble Kinsmen. He battles with Palamon to win the hand of Emilia. Though victorious, he dies when thrown from his horse after the battle and Theseus allows Palamon to marry Emilia.
Daughter of Merops of Percote, a seer, and wife of the future Trojan king, Priam.
Famous writer of old Greek Tragedy in the 5th century B.C.

birth.date: mid 1st century B.C. - early 1st century A.D.

note.p: Wife of A. Ceacina Paetus, who had be ordered to commit suicide for rebellion against Claudius and the Roman Empire. She stabbed herself in order to alleviate her husband's fear of death.
Greek goddess of child birth, virginity, and the hunt. She was thought to be the daughter of Zeus and Leto and the twin sister of Apollo.
Canaanite fertility goddess.
A demon.
Semitic goddess of fertility and love.
Daughter of Cranaus, who named the region of Attica after her early death.
The consort of Cybele whose priests were eunuchs as well as the Phrygian god of vegetation.
Eldest daughter of Zeus, who was condemned to earth when Zeus found out that she was working with Hera to secure prosperity for Hera's son, Eurystheus, over Heracles.

Balin and his brother Balan are two tragic Arthurian figures, brothers who despite their nobility end up killing one another. Their story is recounted in Malory's Morte d'Arthur, Tennyson's Idylls of the King, and Swinburne's The Tale of Balen.
French republican in the mid-nineteenth century who was sentenced to life in prison twice for trying to overthrow the monarchy.
In ancient Greece, a devotee of Bacchus.
English poet and artist.
French politician and historian. Influential in the development of socialism, especially in France.
Italian author, wrote the Decameron. Friend and correspondent of Petrarch.
English writer. Author of A Year in a Lancashire Garden (London: Macmillan, 1879).
English poet. Author of Sonnets from the Portuguese and Aurora Leigh.
English poet famous for his use of dramatic monologue.
Italian philosopher who was burned at the stake in Rome because of the perceived heresy of his philosophy.
A Roman senator, who played a leading role in the assination of Julius Caesar.
English artist and designer during the late Pre-raphelite movement.
English explorer and ethnologist. Best now for his explorations within Asia and Africa. Friend of Swinburne.
A Phonecian who became the founder of the ancient city of Thebes.
Mother of the five Cairoli brothers, Italian patriots, all of whom fought and four of whom died in the struggle for Italian unification.
Greek poet and scholar in the 3rd century B.C.
A Dominician who played a role in bringing the papacy backed to Rome (from Avignon) and establishing peace among the Italian city-states.
Roman poet.
English translator, dramatist, and poet.
Mother of Tiresias, the blind Cadmean prophet. According to the Greek poet, Callimachus, she begged Athena to restore Tiresias's vision, which lead Athena to give him foresight.
English poet, writer, and statesman. Wrote the The Canterbury Tales.

death.date: Around the beginning of the 4th century BC

note.p: Greek epic poet.
English poet and critic. One of the founders of Romanticism. Cowrote Lyrical Ballads.
Greek epic poet.
Greek poet.
Roman Emperor from 306 to 337 who is well known for converting to Christianity and issuing the Edict of Milan in 313 wich proclaimed tolerance of all religions throughout the empire.
17th-century French tragic dramatist.
Famous Roman mother and wife. Wife of Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus and mother of the Gracchi, her two sons, both statesmen and social reformers who were killed in political violence.
Thracian goddess of immodesty and debauchery, who is worshipped with orgiastic rites of song and dance.
English soldier and statesman, lord protector of the republican Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland (1653-58).

The Anatolian Earth Goddess and "Great Mother of the Gods" whose worship was characterized by ecstatic states and insensibility to pain. Her cult was based in Phyrgia and spread to Asia Minor and Greece.
Florentine poet during the Middle Ages. Wrote the Divine Comedy.
The most important Greek oracle and consultant of the growing Greek empire. Also known as the Oracle or priestess of Apollo.
Son of Zeus and Semele and Greek god of wine and ecstasy.
She was the wife of Lycus, who had been killed by Amphion and Zethus for the maltreatment of their mother, Antipone, by tying her to the horns of a bull.
Ancient Greek oracle, possibly the oldest of the oracles. She was located in the northwest part of Greece and typically would advise people on personal issues.
Illustrator. His work appeared frequently in Punch magazine.
A Thracian tribe living about Mount Pangaeüs. Known in myth for the persection of Bacchus and his followers by the Edonian King Lycurgus.
Greek Stoic philosopher and former slave.
Wife of Orpheus. She was killed when bitten by a snake and sent to the Underworld, where Orpheus entered to get her back.
Goddesses of beauty and charm and attendants of Aphrodite.
Born Pierre Roger de Beaufort. Pope from 1370 to 1378. Gregory XI was the last of the Avignon Popes.
Goddess of harmony and concord and daughter of Ares and Aphrodite. She married Cadmus and became Queen of Thebes.
German writer and poet. Lived in Paris after 1831.
Son of Zeus and Alcmene and Greek hero.
Son of Aphrodite and Hermes. He was transformed into an androgynous being due to his encounter with the naiad, Salmacis.
Germanic earth and fertility goddess.
Nymphs who live in a garden in the Arcadian Mountains on the western extreme of the Mediterranean. In the garden, they guard the tree of golden apples given by Gaia to Hera upon her marriage to Zeus.
Amazonian Queen abducted by Theseus. She was Theseus' first wife. In Greek mythology she possessed a magical girdle given to her by her father, Ares, the god of war.
Son of Theseus. He was killed when his startled horses dragged him to his death. In Greek mythology, Theseus employed the gods to kill his son because of his supposed rape of Phaedra.

birth.date: Between the 8th century and 9th century BC

death.date: Between the 8th century and 9th century BC

note.p: Greek epic poet. Attributed having written the Iliad and the Odyssey.
French writer, novelist, playwright, and poet who was idolized by Swinburne. Wrote The Hunchback of Notre Dame.
A prostitute who was occassionally the subject of Catullus' poetry.
In the story of Tristan and Iseult, she is supposed to marry King Mark of Cornwall. But in route to the king, she and Tristan accidentely consume a love potion and fall in love with one another.
Major Egyptian goddess. Embodiment of maternal power and virtue. Mother of Horus, first ruler of a united Egypt.
Son of Aedon. He was accidently killed by Aedon when in envy she tried to kill Niobe's eldest son.

death.date: Between the second and forth decade in the 1st century AD

note.p: Born to Mary and Joseph in Bethlehem. According to most Christian faiths, Jesus, the Son of God, was born of the Virgin Mary, who conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit. Jesus was a religious leader proclaiming the coming of God's kingdom and was crucified by order of the Roman prefect, Pontius Pilate, for high treason.
A military leader who led the French in several victories over the English in the Hundred Years War. She was captured in 1430 and burned at the stake for heresy.
One of the Twelve disciples of Jesus. He betrayed Jesus's location to Jewish authorities for money.
Roman Emperor from 361 to 363 and also a philosopher who purged the top-heavy state bureaucracy and attempted to revive traditional Roman religious practices instead of Christianity
English poet.
Legendary British leader who led the British defense againt the Saxon invaders in the beginning of the 6th century.
A character in Dante Aligheri's Purgatory, thought to be based upon Pia Tolomei, who was killed in 1295 on the orders of her husband.
English/Welsh essayist.
English Romantic poet. Author of Gebir. Republican.
New Testament figure, raised from the dead by Christ (John 11:1-43).

French editor and publisher, known as a publisher of many of the Paranssian poets in his three-volume collection Le Parnasse contemporain (1866, 1871, 1876). Edited Le Tombeau de Théophile Guatier (1871), in which Swinburne's work appears.
An Italian poet, writer, and philosopher.
In Roman mythology, the godess of corpses and funerals.
Roman Emperor from 308 to 324 who coauthored the Edict of Milan and was eventually executed on the orders of Constantine I.
A pseudonymn for Valumnia Cytheris, a freedwoman, actress, and mistress of Mark Antony and Cornelius Gallus, given her by Gallus in his four books of elegies.
English Elizabethan playwright and contemporary of William Shakespeare. His Tamburlaine was one of the first English plays in free verse, the form later made famous by Shakespeare.
French aristocrat, revolutionary politician, philosopher, and writer famous for his libertine sexuality and lifestyle.
One of the inner circle of followers of Jesus. She witnessed the crucifixtion and was one of the first witnesses of Jesus' resurrection.
Mother of Jesus. Known as the Virgin Mary because she was said to have conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit.

Sole surviving legitimate child of King James VI, King of Scotland. She was made queen of Scotland at six days old. She was imprisoned in Loch Leven Castle and later executed by Queen Elizabeth the First for fear she would abdicate the English crown.
Italian patriot, idolized by Swinburne.

The son of Althaea, the queen of Calydon, whose love for Atalanta led to his killing of Althaea's brothers and, in turn, his death when Althaea intentionally placed a brand on the fire that the fates had predicted would bring the end of Meleager' life.
Seventeenth-century English poet. Author of Paradise Lost and Samson Agonistes. Republican and official in Cromwell's Commonwealth.
English painter, poet, and artist. Friend of Swinburne, associated with the Pre-Raphelite movement.
Son of a sheppard, who witnessed the presence of God in a buring bush near Horeb in the Sinai region of Egypt. He was given the Ten Commandments and told to lead the Hebrews out of Egypt.

person.persName: Napoleon I, Emperor of the French

note.p: French general during the later years of the Revolution (1788-1799) and, later, the Consul and renown Emperor of France.
Roman emperor from 54-68 C.E.. Known for being the emperor during the great fire of Rome in 64 C.E..

Wife of Tantalus, the King of ancient Sipylus, who gave birth to 14 children. In Greek mythology her bragging about her fertility upset Leto, who employed her 2 children, Apollo and Artemis to kill Niobe's children.
Thebean king, who, according to Sophocles, unknowingly killed his father and marries his mother.
Son of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra. He killed his mother in revenge for her murder of Agamemnon.
He was considered the greatest musician and poet of Greek myth, who used his song most notably to save the Argonauts from the Sirens and to attempt bringing his wife back from the Underworld.
He tried to usurp the Athenian crown from Thesues, but was killed in an ambush near Gargettus.
Daughter of Helios, the sun, and wife of King Minos of Crete. A curse by Posiedon forced her to copulate with a bull and give birth to the Minotaur.

A immortal, winged horse who carried the thunder and lightening of Zeus. It was said that the Pegasus would make a spring every time it stamped its hoof on the ground. Hippocrene on Mt. Helicon was thought to be one of the Pegasean-made springs.
Early Christian ascetic and theologian.

A king of Thebes and son of Agave and Cadmus. According to Euripidies, Pentheus unknowingly imprisons a disguised Dionysus. In retribution, Dionysus has Pentheus torn apart by a group of maenads led by Pentheus's mother.
One of the twelve apostles. Originally named Simon, but given the name Peter by Jesus. Attributed with 1 & 2 Peter.
Second wife of Theseus. She killed herself because her lie about Hippolytus raping her led to his death.
Ancient Greek Lyrical poet.
King of Troezen, a city in northeastern Peloponnese. He alone understood the prophesies of Aegeus, one of the founders legendary Athens.
The seven daughters of the Titan, Atlas, who accompanied Artemis.
Wife of Brutus, who was the leader in assassination of Julius Ceasar.
Welsh squire and poet. Swinburne's roundels A Dead Friend, Past Days, and Autumn and Winter, memorialize Powell without naming him explicitly.
In Greek mythology, a god of fertility.
A Sophist, travelling teacher of higher education, particularly Rhethoric. He was a contemporary of Socrates.
Goddess of the Underworld and daughter or Zeus and Demeter in Greek mythology. Called Persephone by the Greeks and Proserpina or Proserpine by the Romans.
English poet. Sister of Dante Gabriel and William Michael Rossetti. Friend of Swinburne's.

Victorian English writer, artist, art critic and theorist, and social commentator. Famous works include Modern Painters, The Stones of Venice,, and his autobiography Praeterita. Ruskin was a passionate supporter of J.M.W. Turner, a champion of the Pre-Raphaelites, and a friend of Swinburne.
Italian politican during the Italian unification period. Friend of Giuseppe Mazzini.
A naiad who rejected the viriginal ways of the Greek goddess, Artemis, and whose attempted rape of Hermaphroditus led to their being eternally united as an androgynous being.
Ancient Greek lyric poet between the 6th and 7th centuries B.C.E. Born on the island of Lesbos.

person.persName: Semiramis, Queen, consort of Shamshi-Adad V, King of Assyria, 9th cent. B.C.

note.p: She was the Sammu-ramat, wife of Shamshi-Adad V of Assyria. In Greek myth, she conquered Bactria and founder Babylon; in Armenian legend, she conquered Armenia.
English Elizabethan playwright and poet, idolized by Swinburne and other Victorians. He wrote Hamlet.
English Romantic poet. Author of Prometheus Unbound. Republican.

One of the Knights of the Round Table. In the story of Tristan and Iseult, he is sent to bring Iseult from Ireland to wed his uncle, King Mark of Cornwall. Yet while returning to England, Tristan and Iseult accidentely consume a love potion and fall in love with one another.

An Italian Mannerist painter, who spent the majority of his life in Siena in the Tuscan region of central Italy. He is best known for his frescoes of St. Catherine of Siena in ecstacy after receiving the Eucharist in the San Domenico church. His last name, Bazzi, was often misrepresented as Razzi.
Athenian tragic playwright. Wrote Oedipus Rex.

In Greek mythology, a hybrid creature, part human, part animal. In Thebean legend, the sphinx was a threatening monster that lived in the western mountains of Thebes killing anyone who passed through its territory and couldn't answer its riddle.
Swinburne's youngest sister.
English dramatist.
English poet, who later became poet laureate of England. Wrote In Memoriam A.H.H..
Legendary king of Athens. In greek mythology, he slayed the Minotaur.
Most often referred to as a sea nymph in Greek mythology, but also sometimes referred to as a goddess or the creator of the universe.
In ancient Greece, a female devotee of Bacchus.
A legendary seer for the Cadmeans of Thebes, who had been given foresight to replace his loss of vision.
Friend of poets Byron and Shelley.
Roman goddess of love, beauty, and fertility. Associated with the Greek goddess, Aphrodite.
Roman goddess of the hearth and home.
Mother of famous Roman general, Coriolanus, who was exiled from Rome. Persuaded Coriolanus to not invade Rome.
French philosopher and writer. Major figure of the Enlightenment. Author of Candide.
English critic and poet. Friend of Swinburne's. Watts was instrumental in saving Swinburne from alcoholism. Swinburne lived with Watts in Putney from 1879 until Swinburne's death.
English Jacobean playwright and late contemporary of William Shakespeare. He wrote The Duchess of Malfi.
English writer best known for his nonfiction work, Sappho: memoir, text, selected renderings, and a literal translation.
American-born, English painter. Influenced by the Pre-Raphaelites. Painted Whistler's Mother.
An American poet and proponent of transcendentalism, the idea that the human mind can transcend the physical world on its own. Sometimes called the father of free verse.
English poet and Republican. Co-wrote Lyrical Ballads. One of the founders of the Romantic movement.

In ancient Greece, a female follower of Bacchus, traditionally associated with divine possession and frenzied rites. These were typically upper-class women, who, every other winter, go up into the Greek mountains to perform a ritual urged by Dionysus.

person.note: Early Welsh poet who mentions Arthur in his work.

note.p: Declared on September 21, 1792 with the disposing of Louis XVI. Came to an end when Napoleon declared himself emperor of France in 1804.
The national museum of France located in Paris, which opened August 10, 1793.
A school of painting in Siena, Italy that flourished between the 13th and 15th century.
One of the oldest art museums in the world, built in Florence, Italy in 1581.

A battle between the Spanish and English naval armies near Gravelines, France in the English Channel. Though the Spanish fleet only lost 4 of its 130 ships during the battle, over 50 ships were lost in retreat. The defeat marked the beginning of the end of Spanish dominance in Europe.
The Vatican council of 1870, at which the dotrine of Papal infallibility was established.
French and Papal armies numbering 9000 defeat Garibaldi's forces numbering 4000.
The largest of series of Cretan Christian uprisings against the Ottoman Empire that last from 1866-1869.

A encounter that occured on August 29, 1862 in southern Italy between the Italian government and the Italian Unificationists. The Unificationist leader, Garibaldi, was wounded and taken prisoner during the battle.
A series of battles between Parliamentarians and Royalists. The civil war resulted in the execution of King Charles I and the establishment of the Commonwealth of England.
A battle fought by the Trebbia river in northern Italy between the French and the Austrians and Russians. Both sides lost 6,000 soldiers, but the Austro-Russian army was victorious.

Supporters of Mary, Queen of Scotland and her new husband, James Hepburn, Earl of Bothwell, uprise against Queen Elizabeth I a few miles east of Ediburgh, Scotland. Mary I is captured, imprisoned in Loch Leven Castle, and later executed.

A wave of targeted assassinations and subsequent Roman Catholic mob violence against the Huguenots. The events began on the 23 August 1572, the eve of St. Bartholomew's feast day, with murders ordered by Charles IX of France. The massacres lasted several weeks, and spread throughout Paris and then to other urban centers and the country side.
One of four Athenian festivals honoring Dionysus.
An inlet of the Barents Sea, located in northwest Russia.
A region of southern Italy that was at the center of Italian republicanism during the middle of the 19th century.
A kingdom in the west central portion of Anatolia, in what is now modern-day Turkey.
A town in the Rivigo province in northern Italy.
A body of water that is part of the Mediterranean Sea and separates the Italian peninsula from the Balkan peninsula.
A river in central Italy. It was the main waterway of Rome.
The world's largest continent, which spans from the Pacific in the East to the Indiana Ocean in the south, and Artic in the north.
Consists of the western part of Eurasia that enxtends from Iceland and Russia south to Greece.
Captal of Greece. An important cultural center in ancient Greece, home of Plato's Academy, and bithplace of Socrates and Sophocles.
An ancient city in southern Boetia, a region in central Greece, that was one of the major ancient Greek settlements. It was founded by Cadmus.
Mountain in central Greece, in southwest Boeotia, near the Gulf of Corinth. The mountain was said to be sacred to the muses.
Garden outside Jerusalem on the Mount of Olives. The site where Jesus prayed after the last supper and where He was arrested by Roman soldiers.
Largest of the Greek islands. Site of the first European civilization and later part of the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Empire.
A region in the Peloponnesus, a penisula in sourthern Greece.
A spring in Thebes. Named for Dirce, who was killed by the two sons of Antiope for Dirce's mistreatment of their mother. They threw her body into the spring that afterwards bore her name.
Cayenne is the capital of French Guiana and a former penal coloney.
Ancient country in W central Asia Minor, now central Turkey.
A city of ancient Greece, near Mount X
A city of ancient Greece, near Mount X
A ancient kingdom in sourtheast Europe that spanned over parts of Bulgaria, Turkey, and Greece.
The field bought with the money Judas received for betraying Christ.
A region in central Italy considered to be the birthplace of the Renaissance.
Mountain range in Southern Greece, south west of Sparta.
Site outside ancient Jersusalem, where, according to the Bible, Jesus was crucified.
Mountain range in central Greece, separating Boeotia from Megaris and Attica. These mountains were said to be sacred to Dionysus and were the setting for several Greek myths.
Narrow pass linking Greece with the north, between Thessaly and Locris. The site of a famous battle in 480 BC between the Greeks and Persians.
Island off the south-west coast of Attica. It was the site, in September 480 BC, of the great naval defeat of the Persians by the Greeks.
Name given to the land located in Germany, west of the Rhine. The land was annexed by the Prussian government after the fall of the French emprire in the early 19th century.
A country in southern Europe that includes the Italian Penisula and the islands of Sicily and Sardinia. It was the birthplace of the Renaissance and center of the Roman Empire.
Large Greek deme (local community or parish) on the north-east coast of Attica. The site in 490 BC of a great Greek victory over invading Persians.
Principal river of Laconia, a region of Greece. Named for an early king of Laconia.
A river in northern Italy.
A river that runs through Attica and the Athenean plains in Greece.
The Pines, 11 Putney Hill, Putney, a district of south-west London. Swinburne lived here with his friend Theodore Watts-Dunton, from 1879 until Swinburne's in 1909.
A sea loch or bay on the west coast of Scotland.
A town in northwest Suffolk county in England.
Undercliff southwest England that stetches for five miles.
A parish and market town in Berwickshire, Scotland.
A villiage on the eastern coast of Northumberland in England.
A dependant state of England in the off the coast of Normandy that includes the island of Guernsey and various other islands in the English Channel.
A legendary city located in present day northwest Turkey. In Homer's Iliad it was the center of the Trojan War.
A comune in the province of Rome in Italy.
Country in southeast Europe and site of the first European civilization.
A city-state of ancient Mesopetamia. First appeared as a small town in the 23rd century B.C. It became the center of the Neo-Baylonian Empire in 6th century B.C.
A comune in the province of Florence in Italy that is located on a hill which overlooks the city of Florence.
A geopolitical region between Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. The area includes the Caucasus Mountains, which separate Europe from Asia.
Country located in western Europe, bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the west, the English Channel to the north, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.
Country in central Europe located to the north of Czech Republic and to the east of Germany.
The largest country in the world, which spans multiple continents over much of northern Eurasia.

A landlocked country in western Europe bordered by France to the west, Germany to the north, Italy to the south, and Austria to the east. During the Napoleonic Wars, Switzerland was invaded by Austria and Russia. It was in Switzerland where Giuseppe Mazzini met Garibaldi.
A country in western Europe to the east of Switzerland and north of Italy. The country was in constant war during the 19th century with France and Prussia.
Country located in southwestern Europe in the Iberian Peninsula.
A country in the southern part of the North American continent. Separated from England in the late 18th century.
The capital of the Tuscany region in Italy and an important cultural center during the Renaissance.
Capital of Italy.
Island to the north of continental Europe. Part of the United Kingdom, along with Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.
A country in the northern part of central Europe that became an independent nation-state in 1871.
Body of the water enclosed by Europe to the North, Africa to the South, and Asia to the East. It was an important trade and travel route for Ancient civilizations.
The Greek and Roman name for the Underworld. Thought to be the only destination of the dead, unitl 5th century B.C..
Large reason in northern Israel, originally divided into Upper Galilee, Lower Galilee, and Western Galilee.
A city in ancient Syria founded by Seleucus Nicator, one of Alexander the Great's generals.
A setion of the Underworld located at the end of the Earth where the distinguished live in pleasure after death.

A mythical European river that is associated with the Po River in Northern Italy. The river into which Phaëthon fell from the sky and by which his sisters, the Heliades, wept until they were changed into poplars. The Argonauts traveled the Eridanus in their quest for the golden fleece.
One of the rivers that runs through the Underworld. The dead drink from this river to forget about their lives on Earth.
From the Anatolian Mount Ida, Zeus was said to have abducted Ganymede to Olympus.
A mountain in Phrygia, sacred to Dybele, the mother of the gods.
A river that separates the living world from the Underworld, around which it wraps nine times. Also known as the river of hate.
A star system in the constellation Taurus. The brightest star in the Pleiades open cluster.
A mountain range that stretches north to south on the east coast of the Italian peninsula.
A mountain range in central Europe that borders Spain and France and separates the Iberian peninsula and the rest of central Europe.
A hamlet to the southwest of Fiesole on the Florence border in central Italy.
A church in Siena in the Tuscan region of Italy.
One of the largest and oldest churches in Florence, Italy. Several of the Medici family are buried in the church cemetery.
A city in the Tuscany region of central Italy. It was the home of St, Catherine and the church of San Domenico.
A town of Syria, with a famous temple of Aphrodite, destroyed by Constantine.
A commune in southerneastern France that was the seat of the Papacy from 1309-1377. It became part of France in 1791.
A church located in Siena, Italy, which contains the works of Sodoma and the emtombed head and thumb of Catherine of Siena.
A range of mountains that separates the Iberian peninsula from the rest of Europe.
Ancient inland city of Cyprus, which became a center for the worship of Aphrodite.
An ancient city-kingdom in southwest Cyprus. Also known as the mythological birthplace of Aphrodite and the site of a famous sanctuary to the goddess.
A small island off the coast of Greece. According to certain myths, it is where Aphrodite emerged from the sea.
An ancient royal city in southern Cyprus known for its santuary dedicated to Aphrodite.
A region in western Italy, mostly in the province of Grosseto. It is where Pia Tolomei was killed.
The 2nd largest ocean in the world. It separates North and South American from Europe and Africa.
The world's second largest continent, which is located to the south of Europe.
Town on the edge of Mt. Parnassus in central Greece. In Ancient Greece, it was the site of the Oracle of Delphi and thought to be the center of the world.
Island in the southwestern English Channel, part of the Bailiwick of Gurnsey.
A London theatre built by William Shakespeare's playing company, the Lord Chamberlain's Men, in 1599. It was destroyed by fire in 1613.
A London playhouse in the 17th century.
A playhouse in central London during the Renaissance.
A country in northeast Africa near the Middle East. Site of the ancient Egyptian empire.
A landlocked country in northeast Africa.
An ancient city in Phocis, in central Greece.
Greek island in the northeast Aegean Sea. Birthplace of Sappho.
The largest river in France.
The capital of the Greek island of Lesbos in the Aegean Sea.
An ancient city located in northeastern Turkey.

place.note: A mountain, the site of Arthur's eleventh victory over the Saxons.

monogr.title: A selection from the works of Lord Byron.
monogr.author: Algernon Charles Swinburne

category.gloss: A form of verse Swinburne adapted from the French Rondeau. Consists of nine lines with the same number of syllables. Has the rhyme scheme: A B A B ; B A B ; A B A B. The last lines of the first and third stanzas are the refrain, which is the same as the beginning of the poem's first line.
Topic map on Arthurian legend, including legendary figures, places, and events.
A figure from the various legends and folklore of the world, including Arthurian legend.
A geographic feature, such as the Ohio River, the North Sea, or Mont Blanc.
Lindemans, Micha, ed. Encyclopedia Mythica. 17 August 2004. Encycopedia Mythica. 27 August 2004. <https://pantheon.org/>.

bibl.author: John A. Walsh
bibl.note: Used to classify the bibliographic records for the various published versions of a given text

tagsDecl.rendition: milestone indicated by blank space approximately three lines in height"
sub line group; a subdivision of a line group, such as the octet and sextet of a sonnet, that is a logical group but is not set off typographically.
/* date cell in a chronology table */ font-style: italic;

.indent:before {content: "\A0\A0\A0\A0\A0\A0";} /* Should be implmented as .indent {text-indent: 4em;}, but a bug in Safari causes block elements to re-indent when interrupted by another block element. */>
Used in rendition of q or quote for inline quoted speech or quotations that are not marked with quotation marks.
Indicates a element such as castItem is rendered in list form.
Indicates that a block in a list (e.g., a castGroup in a CastList) is marked by a brace to the right of the list block.

encodingDesc.p:
Unfamiliar names—names of real or fictional people/places/institutions/events that would be unfamiliar to some readers—occur frequently in these documents. Such names are identified by associating the name with this explanation. For example:
Joseph Mazzini

entry.def: Twisting, twisted, tortuous.tortive, a. The Oxford English Dictionary. 2nd ed. 1989. OED Online. Oxford University Press. 4 Apr. 2000 .
The working of wonders; miracle-working; magic. thaumaturgy The Oxford English Dictionary. 2nd ed. 1989. OED Online. Oxford University Press. 28 Jan 2009 .
A tomb or monument erected for one whose remains are elsewhere.
Waxed, waterproof cloth, used for wrapping dead bodies.

A church service observed during the final part of Holy Week in commemoration of the sufferings and death of Christ. The service includes the public chanting of psalms and the progressive extinguishing of all candles until only one remains burning behind or under the altar.
At or forming the top or highest point.

body.head: Byron.
body.p: [Prefatory Note.—This, like the following essay, was prefixed to a small volume of selections from the poems of the author whose genius is the subject of discussion. To the work of Coleridge this process of selection, if adequately carried out, must have been, as Leigh Hunt long since suggested, a real and great service; for his work is distinctly divisible into good and bad, durable and perishable; and it would be a clear gain to have the priceless parts of that work detached from the worthless; but to Byron, who rarely wrote anything either worthless or faultless, it could not be otherwise than injurious. He can only be judged or appreciated in the mass; the greatest of his works was his whole work taken altogether; and to know or to honour him aright he must be considered with all his imperfections and with all his glories on his head.]

The most delicate and thoughtful of English critics has charged the present generation of Englishmen with forgetfulness of Byron. It is not a light charge: and it is not ungrounded. Men born when this century was getting into its forties were baptized into another church
than his with the rites of another creed. Upon their ears, first after the cadences of elder poets, fell the faultless and fervent melodies of Tennyson. To them, chief among the past heroes of the younger century, three men appeared as predominant in poetry; Coleridge, Keats, and Shelley. Behind these were effaced, on either hand, the two great opposing figures of Byron and Wordsworth. No man under twenty can just now be expected to appreciate these. The time was when all boys and girls who paddled in rhyme and dabbled in sentiment were wont to adore the presence or the memory of Byron with foolish faces of praise. It is of little moment to him or to us that they have long since ceased to cackle and begun to hiss. They have become used to better verse and carefuller workmen; and must be forgiven if after such training they cannot at once appreciate the splendid and imperishable excellence which covers all his offences and outweighs all his defects: the excellence of sincerity and strength. Without these no poet can live; but few have ever had so much of them as Byron. His sincerity indeed is difficult to discover and define; but it does in effect lie at the root of all his good works: deformed by pretension and defaced by assumption, masked by folly and veiled by affectation; but perceptible after all, and priceless.

It is no part of my present office to rewrite the history of a life in which every date and event that could be given would now seem trite and stale to all possible readers. If, after so many promises and hints, something at once new and true shall at length be unearthed or extricated, which may affect for the better or the worse our judgment of the man, it will be possible and necessary to rewrite it Meantime this among other chances “lies on the lap of the gods;“and especially on the lap of a goddess who still treads our earth. Until she speaks, we cannot guess what she may have to say; and can only pass by with reverent or with sceptical reticence. It will be evident that these lines were written before the appearance of the book in which Madame de Boissy thought fit to let the world know that she had nothing to tell worth its hearing with regard to the man whose love had made her famous, but was not the less willing to put forth that nothing in two leaden volumes of verbiage. The worst consequence of this miscarriage was not the collapse of such faint hopes or surmises as we might yet have cherished of some benefit to be received in the way of biography, some new and kindly light to be thrown on the life and character of Byron; it was the opportunity given to a filthy female moralist and novelist who was not slow to avail herself of such an occasion “to expound her beastly mind to all.” Evidently the laurels of Mrs. Behn had long kept her successor from sleeping; it was not enough to have copied the authoress of “Oroonoko” in the selection of a sable and a servile hero; her American imitator was bent on following her down fouler ways than this. But I feel that an apology is due to the virtuous memory of the chaste Aphra; she was indeed the first “nigger novelist,” and she was likewise a vendor and purveyor of obscene fiction; but here the parallel ends; for I am not aware that she ever applied her unquestionable abilities in that unlovely line of business to the defamation at second hand of the illustrious and defenceless dead.

Thus much however we may safely assert: that no man’s work was ever more influenced by his character; and that no man’s character was ever more influenced by his circumstances. Rather from things without than from things within him did the spirit of Byron assume colour and shape. His noblest verse leapt on a sudden
into life after the heaviest evils had fallen upon him which even he ever underwent. From the beginning indeed he had much to fight against; and three impediments hung about him at starting, the least of which would have weighed down a less strong man: youth, and genius, and an ancient name.That his youth and his rank were flung in his face with vulgar insolence on the publication of his first little book it can hardly be necessary to remind any reader of Byron; but possibly even these offences might have been condoned in a scribbler whose work had given no offensive promise of greatness yet to be. In the verses on Lochnagar at least an ominous threat or presage of something new and splendid must have been but too perceptible to the discerning eye of criticism. In spite of all three he made his way; and suffered for it. At the first chance given or taken, every obscure and obscene thing that lurks for pay or prey among the fouler shallows and thickets of literature flew against him; every hound and every hireling lavished upon him the loathsome tribute of their abuse; all nameless creatures that nibble and prowl, upon whom the serpent’s curse has fallen, to go upon his belly and eat dust all the days of his life, assailed him with their foulest venom and their keenest fangs. And the promise given of old to their kind was now at least fulfilled: they did bruise his heel. But the heads of such creatures are so small that it is hard to bruise them in return; it would first be necessary to discern them.

It is natural in writing of Byron to slide into remembrances of what is likest to his verse. His work and Shelley’s, beyond that of all our other poets, recall or suggest the wide and high things of nature; the large likeness of the elements; the immeasurable liberty and the stormy strength of waters and winds. They are strongest when they touch upon these; and it is worth remark how few are the poets of whom this can be said. Here, as elsewhere, Shakespeare is supreme when it pleased him; but it pleased him rarely. No poetry of shipwreck and the sea has ever equalled the great scene of “Pericle’s;“no such note of music was ever struck out of the dash and contention of tempestuous elements. In Milton the sublimity is chiefly of sound; the majesty of melodies unsurpassed from all time well-nigh excludes and supplants all other motives of material beauty. In the minds of mediaeval poets there was no width or depth to receive and contain such emotion. In Spenser, despite his fertile and fluent ingenuity, his subtle and sleepy graces, the effeminacy of colour no less than the monotony of metre makes it hopeless to look for any trace of that passionate sense of power and delight in great outer things of which we speak here. Among later men, Coleridge and Keats used nature mainly as a stimulant or a sedative; Wordsworth as a vegetable fit to shred into his pot and pare down like the outer leaves of a lettuce for didactic and culinary purposes. I remember some critical cackling over this phrase when it first appeared as over a senseless insult offered to the name and genius of a great poet. Insult is no habit of mine; and the term here used implies no more than he that runs may read in the text of Wordsworth; in whom, after the somewhat early subsidence of that “simple, sensuous, and passionate” delight in nature of which in two of his most famous poems he has for ever embalmed his recollection, the place of this rapturous instinct of submission and absorption, which other poets have been who never have ceased to feel in sight of natural glory and beauty, was taken by a meditative and moralizing spirit too apt to express itself in the tone of a preacher to whom all the divine life of things outside man is but as raw material for philosophic or theological cookery. How far this method of contemplating and interpreting the splendours and terrors of nature differs from that of his greatest contemporaries it is surely neither irrelevant nor impertinent to point out once more. Wide apart as lay their lines of work, it is true alike of Shelley and of Keats that for them it was not fated, nor could it ever have been possible, to outlive
“The hour
Of splendour in the grass, of glory in the flower;”
nor could Byron, while retaining as did Wordsworth the freshness and the force of his genius, have outlived his more fiery delight in the triumphant life of sea and cloud and storm. All these
doubtless in their own fashion loved her, for her beauties, for her uses, for her effects; hardly one for herself.

Turn now to Byron or to Shelley. These two at least were not content to play with her skirts and paddle in her shallows. Their passion is perfect a fierce and blind desire which exalts and impels their verse into the high places of emotion and expression. They feed upon nature with a holy hunger follow her with a divine lust as of gods chasing the daughters of men. Wind and fire, the cadences of thunder and the clamours of the sea, gave to them no less of sensual pleasure than of spiritual sustenance. These things they desired as others desire music or wine or the beauty of women. This outward and indifferent nature of things, cruel in the eyes of all but her lovers, and even in theirs not loving, became as
pliant to their grasp and embrace as any Clymene or Leucothea to Apollo’s. To them the large motions and the remote beauties of space were tangible and familiar as flowers. Of this poetry, where description melts into passion and contemplation takes fire from delight, the highest sample is Shelley’s “Ode to the West Wind.” An imperfect mastery of his materials keeps the best things of Byron some few degrees below an equal rank One native and incurable defect grew up and strengthened side by side with his noblest qualities: a feeble and faulty sense of metre. No poet of equal or inferior rank ever had so bad an ear. His smoother cadences are often vulgar and facile; his fresher notes are often incomplete and inharmonious. His verse stumbles and jingles, stammers and halts, where there is most need for a swift and even pace of musical sound. The rough sonorous changes of the songs in the “Deformed Transformed” rise far higher in harmony and strike far deeper into the memory than the lax easy lines in which he at first indulged; but they slip too readily into notes as rude and weak as the rhymeless tuneless verse in which they are so loosely set, as in a cheap and casual frame. The magnificent lyric measures of “Heaven and Earth” are defaced by the coarse obtrusion of short lines with jagged edges: no small offence in a writer of verse. Otherwise these choral scenes are almost as blameless as they are brilliant. The poet who above others took delight in the sense of sounding storms and shaken waters could not but exult over the vision of deluge with all his strength and breadth of wing. Tempest and rebellion and the magnificence of anguish were as the natural food and fire
to kindle and sustain his indomitable and sleepless spirit. The godless martyrdom of rebels; the passion that cannot redeem; the Thebaid whose first hermit was Cain, the Calvary whose first martyr was Satan; these, time after time, allured and inspired him. Here for once this inner and fiery passion of thought found outer clothing and expression in the ruin of a world. Both without and within, the subject was made for him, and lay ready shapen for the strong impressure of his hand. His love of wide and tempestuous waters fills his work throughout as with the broad breath of a sea-wind. Even the weakest of his poems, a thing still-born and shapeless, is redeemed and revived by one glorious verse:— “When the Poles crashed, and water was the world.”

This passion and power in dealing with the higher things of nature, with her large issues and remote sources, has been bestowed upon Victor Hugo alone among our contemporaries. He also can pass beyond the idyllic details of landscape, and put out from shore into the wide waste places of the sea. And this of course is the loftiest form of such poetry as deals with outward nature and depends upon the forms of things. In Byron the power given by this passion is the more conspicuous through his want of dramatic capacity. Except in the lighter and briefer scenes of “Don Juan,” he was never able to bring two speakers face to face and supply them with the right words. In structure as in metre his elaborate tragedies are wholly condemnable; filled as they are in spirit with the overflow of his fiery energy. “Cain” and “Manfred” are properly monologues decorated and set off
by some slight appendage of ornament or explanation. In the later and loftier poem there is no difference perceptible, except in strength and knowledge, between Lucifer and Cain. Thus incompetent to handle the mysteries and varieties of character, Byron turns always with a fresh delight and a fresh confidence thither where he feels himself safe and strong. No part of his nature was more profound and sincere than the vigorous love of such inanimate things as were in time with his own spirit and senses. His professions of contempt were too loud to express it; scorn is brief or silent; anger alone finds vent in violent iteration and clamorous appeal. He had too much of fury and not enough of contempt; he foams at things and creatures not worth a glance or a blow. But when once clear of men and confronted with elements, he casts the shell of pretence and drops the veil of habit; then, as in the last and highest passage of a poem which has suffered more from praise than any other from dispraise, his scorn of men caught in the nets of nature and necessity has no alloy of untruth; his spirit is mingled with the sea’s, and overlooks with a superb delight the ruins and the prayers of men.

This loftiest passage in “Childe Harold” has been so often mouthed and mauled by vulgar admiration that it now can scarcely be relished. Like a royal robe worn out, or a royal wine grown sour, it seems the worse for having been so good. But in fact, allowing for one or two slips and blots, we must after all replace it among the choice and high possessions of poetry. After the first there is hardly a weak line; many have a wonderful vigour and melody; and the deep and glad disdain of
the sea for men and the works of men passes nto the verse in music and fills it with a weighty and sonorous harmony grave and sweet as the measured voice of heavy remote waves. No other passage in the fourth canto will bear to be torn out from the text; and this one suffers by extraction. The other three cantos are more loosely built and less compact of fabric; but in the first two there is little to remember or to praise. Much of the poem is written throughout in falsetto; there is a savour in many places as of something false and histrionic. This singular and deep defect, which defaces so much of Byron’s work, seems also to have deformed his personal character to have given a twist to his enmities and left a taint upon his friendships. He was really somewhat sombre and sad at heart, and it pleased him to seem sadder than he was. He was impressible and susceptible to pleasure, able to command and enjoy it; and of this also it pleased him to make the most in public. But in fact he was neither a Harold nor a Juan; he was better than these in his own way, and assumed their parts and others with a hypocrisy but half insincere. The fault was probably in great part unconscious, and transparent as a child’s acting. To the keen eye and cool judgment of Stendhal it was at once perceptible. Byron’s letter to him in defence of Scott was doubtless not insincere; yet it is evident that the writer felt himself to be playing a graceful part to advantage. This fretful and petulant appetite for applause, the proper apanage of small poets and lowly aspirants, had in Byron’s case to wrestle with the just pride of place and dignity of genius; no man ever had more of these; yet
they did not always support him; he fell even into follies and vulgarities unworthy of a meaner name than his. In effect, when his errors were gravest, he erred through humility and not through pride. Pride would have sustained him far above the remarks and reviews of his day, the praise or dispraise of his hour. As it was, he was vulnerable even by creeping things; and at times their small stings left a poison behind which turned his blood. The contagion of their touch infected him; and he strove under its influence to hiss and wound as they. Here and there in his letters and reflections, in the loose records of his talk and light fragments of his work, the traces of infection are flagrant.

But these defects were only as scars on the skin, superficial and removable; they are past and done with; while all of him that was true and good remains, as it will to all time. Justice cannot be done to it here or now. It is enough if after careful selection as little injustice be done as possible. His few sonnets, unlike Shelley’s, are all good; the best is that on Bonnivard, one of his noblest and completest poems. The versified narratives which in their day were so admirable and famous have yielded hardly a stray sheaf to the gleaner. They have enough of vigour and elasticity to keep life in them yet; but once chipped or broken their fabric would crumble and collapse. The finest among them is certainly either the “Giaour” or the “Siege of Corinth;” the weakest is probably either “Parisina” or the “Bride of Abydos.” But in none of these is there even a glimpse of Byron’s higher and rarer faculty. All that can be said for them is that they gave tokens of a talent singularly fertile, rapid
and vivid; a certain power of action and motion which redeems them from the complete stagnation of dead verses; a command over words and rhymes never of the best and never of the worst. In the “Giaour,” indeed there is something of a fiery sincerity which in its successors appears diluted and debased. Remembering the success of these stories, we may believe that Byron’s contempt for the critical fashions of a time which extolled his worst work was not wholly affected or assumed; and understand how the instincts of opposition and reaction drove him back into that open idolatry of Pope and his school which he expressed loudly and foolishly enough. Probably at heart he did really prefer Pope to all men. His critical faculty, if I may steal one phrase from a treasury that may well spare me the loan, was “zero, or even a frightful minus quantity;” his judgement never worth the expense of a thought or a word. Besides, he had striven to emulate or at least to copy the exquisite manner of Pope in his satires, and must have seen how great and impassable a gulf lay between the master and his pupil This would naturally lead him to over-estimate what he could not attain: the delicate merit, the keen perfection, the equable balance of force and finish, of sense and style, which raised his favourite so high among writers, if they left him somewhat low among poets; and having himself so bad an ear for metre, he may even have imagined that Pope’s verse was musical.

The change began in Byron when he first found out his comic power, and rose at once beyond sight or shot of any rival. His early satires are wholly devoid of humour, wit, or grace; the verse of “Beppo,” bright and soft and fluent, is full at once of all. The sweet light, music of its few and low notes was perfect as a prelude to the higher harmonies of laughter and tears, of scorn and passion, which as yet lay silent in the future. It is mere folly to seek in English or Italian verse a precedent or a parallel. The scheme of metre is Byron’s alone; no weaker hand than his could ever bend that bow, or
ever will. Even the Italian poets, working in a language more flexible and ductile than ours, could never turn their native metre to such uses, could never handle their national weapon with such grace and strength. The terza rima remains their own, after all our efforts to adapt it; it bears here only forced flowers and crude fruits; I do not of course forget that our own time has produced two noble poems in this foreign and alien metre; but neither “Casa Guidi Windows” nor “The Defence of Guenevere” will suffice to establish its general excellence or fitness. The poets have done so well because they could do no less; but there may be at once good material and good workmanship without good implements. Neither of them has done more to give footing in England to the metre of their poems than did Byron himself by his “Prophecy of Dante.” They have done better than this; but this they have not done. but the ottava rima Byron has fairly conquered and wrested from them: Before the appearance of “Beppo” no one could foresee what a master’s hand might make of the instrument; and no one could predict its further use and its dormant powers before the advent of “Don Juan.” In the “Vision of Judgment” it appears finally perfected; the metre fits the sense as with close and pliant armour, the perfect panoply of Achilles. A poem so short and hasty, based on a matter so worthy of brief contempt and long oblivion as the funeral and the fate of George III., bears about it at first sight no great sign or likelihood of life. But this poem which we have by us stands alone, not in Byron’s work only, but in the work of the world. Satire in earlier times had changed her rags for robes; Juvenal had clothed with fire, and Dryden with majesty, that wandering and bastard Muse. Byron gave her wings to fly with, above the reach even of these.
Others have had as much of passion and as much of humour; Dryden had perhaps as much of both combined. But here and not elsewhere a third quality is apparent: the sense of a high and clear imagination. The grave and great burlesque of King George and St. Peter is relieved and sustained by the figures of Michael and Satan. These two, confronted and corresponding as noon and night, lift and light up the background of satire, bloodred or black according to the point of view. Above all, the balance of thought and passion is admirable; human indignation and divine irony are alike understood and expressed: the pure and fiery anger of men at sight of wrong-doing, the tacit inscrutable derision of heaven. Upon this light and lofty poem a commentary might be written longer than the text and less worth reading; but here it shall not be. Those who read it with the due delight, not too gravely and not too lightly, will understand more than can now be set down; those who read it otherwise will not understand anything. Even these can hardly fail to admire the vigour and variety of scorn, the beauty and the bitterness of verse, which raise it beyond comparison with any other satire. There is enough and too much of violence and injustice in the lines on Southey; but it must be remembered that he was the first to strike, and with an unfair weapon. A poet by profession, he had assaulted with feeble fury another poet, not on the fair and open charge of bad verses, but under the impertinent and irrelevant plea that his work was an affliction or an offence to religion and morality—the most susceptible as the most intangible, among the creatures of metaphor. A man less irritable
and less powerful than Byron might be forgiven for any reprisals; and the excellence of his verses justifies their injustice. But that Southey, who could win and retain for life the love and the praise of Landor, was capable of conscious baseness or falsity, Byron himself in sober moments should hardly have believed. Between official adoration and not less official horror—between George deified and Byron’s denounced—the Laureate’s position was grotesque enough. It was almost a good office to pelt him with the names of hireling and apostate; these charges he could reject and refute. The facts were surely sufficient: that, as to religion, his “present Deity” was the paltriest maniac among kings and Caesars; as to morality, his feelings or his faith obliged him to decry as pernicious the greatest work of his opponent.

Side by side with the growth of his comic and satiric power, the graver genius of Byron increased and flourished. As the tree grew higher it grew shapelier; the branches it put forth on all sides were fairer of leaf and fuller of fruit than its earlier offshoots had promised. But from these hardly a stray bud or twig can be plucked off by way of sample. No detached morsel of “Don Juan,” no dismembered fragment of “Cain,” will serve to show or to suggest the excellence of either. These poems are coherent and complete as trees or flowers; they cannot be split up and parcelled out like a mosaic of artificial jewellery, which might be taken to pieces by the same artisan who put it together. It must then be remembered that any mere selection from the verse of Byron, however much of care and of goodwill be spent upon the task, must perforce either exclude or impair his very greatest work.
Cancel or select a leaf from these poems, and you will injure the whole framework equally in either case. It is not without reluctance that I have given any extracts from “Don Juan;” it is not without a full sense of the damage done to these extracts by the very act of extraction. But I could only have left them untouched with a reluctance even greater; and this plea, if it can, must excuse me. As fragments they are exquisite and noble, like the broken hand or severed foot of a Greek statue; but here as much is lost as there. Taken with their context, they regain as much of beauty and of force as the sculptured foot or hand when, reunited to the perfect body, they resume their place and office among its vital and various limbs. This gift of life and variety is the supreme quality of Byron’s chief poem; a quality which cannot be expressed by any system of extracts. Little can here be given beyond a sample or two of tragic and serious work. The buoyant beauty of surrounding verse, the “innumerable laughter” and the profound murmur of its many measures, the fervent flow of stanzas now like the ripples and now like the gulfs of the sea, can no more be shown by process of selection than any shallow salt pool left in the sand for sunbeams to drain dry can show the depth and length of the receding tide.

It would be waste of words and time here to enlarge at all upon the excellence of the pure comedy of “Don Juan.” From the first canto to the sixteenth; from the defence of Julia, which is worthy of Congreve or Moliere, to the study of Adeline, which is worthy of Laclos or Balzac; the elastic energy of humour never falters or
flags. English criticism, with a mournful murmur of unanimous virtue, did at the time, and may yet if it please, appeal against the satire which strikes home and approve the satire that flies abroad. It was said, and perhaps is still said, that the poem falls off and runs low towards the end. Those who can discover where a change for the worse begins might at least indicate the landmark, imperceptible to duller eyes, which divides the good from the bad. Others meantime will retain their belief that this cry was only raised because in these latter cantos a certain due amount of satire fell upon the false and corrupt parts of English character, its mealy-mouthed vices and its unsound virtues. Had the scene been shifted to Italy or France, we might have heard little of the poet’s failing power and perverse injustice.

It is just worth a word of notice that Byron, like Fielding before him, has caught up a well-known name and prefixed it to his work, without any attempt or desire to retain the likeness or follow the tradition attached to it. With him Don Juan is simply a man somewhat handsomer and luckier than others of his age. This hero is not even a reduced copy of the great and terrible figure with which he has nothing in common but a name. The Titan of embodied evil, the likeness of sin made flesh, which grew up in the grave and bitter imagination of a Spanish poet, steeped in the dyes and heated by the flames of hell, appears even in the hands of Moliere diminished, and fallen as it were from Satan to Belial: but still splendid with intellect and courage that tower above the meaner minds and weaker wills of women and of men; still inflexible to human appeal and indomitable
by divine anger. To crush him, heaven is compelled to use thunder and hell-fire; and by these, though stricken, he is not subdued. The sombre background of a funereal religion is not yet effaced; but it tasked the whole strength of Moliere, gigantic as that strength was, to grapple with the shadow of this giant, to transfigure upon a new stage the tragic and enormous incarnation of supreme sin. As it is, even when playing with his debtors or his peasants, the hero of Moliere retains always some feature of his first likeness, some shadow of his early shape. But further than France the terrible legend has never moved. Rigid criticism would therefore say that the title of Byron’s masterpiece was properly a misnomer: which is no great matter after all, since the new Juan can never be confounded with the old.

Of Byron’s smaller poems there is less to say, and less space to say it. Their splendid merits and their visible defects call neither for praise nor blame. Their place and his, in the literature of England, are fixed points: no critical astronomy of the future can lower or can raise them: they have their own station for all time among the greater and the lesser stars. As a poet, Byron was surpassed, beyond all question and all comparison, by three men at least of his own time; and matched, if not now and then overmatched, by one or two others. The verse of Wordsworth, at its highest, went higher than his; the verse of Landor flowed clearer. But his own ground, where none but he set foot, was lofty enough, fertile and various. Nothing in Byron is so worthy of wonder and admiration as the scope and range of his power. New fields and ways of work, had he lived, might have given
room for exercise and matter for triumph to “that most fiery spirit.” The noble verses of Shelley are fitter to be spoken over Byron than over any first or last Napoleon. To no other man could they be so well applied: for the world indeed took more of warmth from the fire of his spirit while alive than from any other then, kindled:—
“What! alive and so bold, O Earth?
Art thou not over-bold?
What! leapest thou forth as of old
In the light of thy morning mirth,
The last of the flock of the starry fold?
* * * * * *
Thou wert warming thy fingers old
O’er the embers covered and cold
Of that most fiery spirit, when it fled:
What, Mother, do you laugh now he is dead?”
As it is, his work was done at Missolonghi; all of his work for which the fates could spare him time. A little space was allowed him to show at least a heroic purpose, and attest a high design; then, with all things unfinished before him and behind, he fell asleep after many troubles and triumphs. Few can ever have gone wearier to the grave; none with less fear. He had done enough to earn his rest Forgetful now and set free for ever from all faults and foes, he passed through the doorway of no ignoble death out of reach of time, out of sight of love, out of hearing of hatred, beyond the blame of England and the praise of Greece. In the full strength of spirit and of body his destiny overtook him, and made an end of all his labours. He had seen and borne and achieved more than most men on record. “He was a great man, good at many things, and now he has attained this also, to be at rest”
